=== Competitive feature films === The festivals in [[Berlin International Film Festival|Berlin]], [[Cairo International Film Festival|Cairo]], [[Cannes Film Festival|Cannes]], [[International Film Festival of India|Goa]], [[Karlovy Vary International Film Festival|Karlovy Vary]], [[Locarno International Film Festival|Locarno]], [[Mar del Plata Film Festival|Mar del Plata]], [[Montreal World Film Festival|Montreal]], [[Moscow International Film Festival|Moscow]], [[San Sebastián International Film Festival|San Sebastián]], [[Shanghai International Film Festival|Shanghai]], [[Tallinn Black Nights Film Festival|Tallinn]], [[Tokyo International Film Festival|Tokyo]], [[Venice Film Festival|Venice]], and [[Warsaw Film Festival|Warsaw]] are accredited by the [[FIAPF|International Federation of Film Producers Associations (FIAPF)]] in the category of competitive feature films.<ref name="FIAPF-competitive">{{cite web |author=International Federation of Film Producers Associations |authorlink=International Federation of Film Producers Associations |title=Competitive Feature Film Festivals |url=http://www.fiapf.org/intfilmfestivals_sites.asp |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040310091402/http://www.fiapf.org/intfilmfestivals_sites.asp |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2004-03-10 |accessdate=2012-07-29 }} </ref>
=== Experimental films === [[Ann Arbor Film Festival]] started in 1963. It is the oldest continually operated experimental film festival in North America, and has become one of the premiere film festivals for independent and, primarily, experimental filmmakers to showcase work.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mrlQtwEACAAJ&dq=ann+arbor+film+festival&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj8o_zK-dPbAhXD5oMKHW3DBC0Q6AEIMzAC|title=THE ANN ARBOR FILM FESTIVAL, 1963-1982: A HISTORY ILLUSTRATING THE GENRES OF AMERICAN AVANT-GARDE CINEMA (EXPERIMENTAL, UNDERGROUND, INDEPENDENT; MICHIGAN).|last=Bradley|first=Ruth Estelle|date=1985|publisher=University of MICHIGAN|language=en}}</ref>
=== Independent films === In the US, [[Telluride Film Festival]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/art/Telluride-Film-Festival|title=Telluride Film Festival|last=|first=|date=|website=Encyclopædia Britannica|access-date=October 11, 2017}}</ref> [[Sundance Film Festival]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/F/FILM_SUNDANCE_ROBERT_REDFORD_GENT-?SITE=WIFON&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|title=Redford Says Sundance Maintains Essence|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/F/FILM_SUNDANCE?SITE=TNNAT&SECTION=ENTERTAINMENT&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|title=Filmmakers look to Sundance buying spree|publisher=}}</ref> [[Austin Film Festival]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.filmthreat.com/festivals/2233/ |title=The Plot Thickens For 2009 Austin Film Festival |publisher=Film Threat |date=2009-02-24 |accessdate=2012-11-23 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121128035424/http://www.filmthreat.com/festivals/2233/ |archive-date=2012-11-28 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> [[Austin, Texas|Austin]]'s [[South by Southwest]], [[New York City]]'s [[Tribeca Film Festival]] and [[Slamdance Film Festival]] are all considered significant festivals for independent film. The [[Zero Film Festival]] is significant as the first and only festival exclusive to self-financed filmmakers.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/brooklyn/zero_film_festival_celebrates_indie_0kJ6FF5Byvr7YUCsCh1GMO/ | work=New York Post | title=Zero Film Festival Celebrates Indie Spirit | date=November 23, 2009}}</ref> The biggest independent film festival in the UK is [[Raindance Film Festival]].<ref name="independent.co.uk"/>
=== North American film festivals === '''The [[San Francisco International Film Festival]]''', founded by Irving "Bud" Levin started in 1957, is the oldest continuously annual film festival in the United States. It highlights current trends in international [[filmmaking]] and [[video production]] with an emphasis on work that has not yet secured U.S. distribution.
'''The [[Toronto International Film Festival]],''' founded by Bill Marshall, Henk Van der Kolk and Dusty Cohl,<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.torontointernationalfilmfestival.ca/abouttiff/organization/tiffhistory |title=Archived copy |access-date=2010-09-21 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100825030348/http://www.torontointernationalfilmfestival.ca/abouttiff/organization/tiffhistory |archive-date=2010-08-25 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> is regarded as North America's most major and most prestigious film festival, and is the most widely attended.
'''The [[Sundance film festival]]''' founded by [[Sterling Van Wagenen]] (then head of Wildwood, Robert Redford's company), John Earle, and Cirina Hampton Catania (both serving on the Utah Film Commission at the time) is a major festival for independent film.
'''The [[Woodstock Film Festival]]''' was launched in 2000 by filmmakers Meira Blaustein and Laurent Rejto with the goal to bring high quality independent film to the [[Hudson Valley]] region of [[New York (state)|New York]]. [[Indiewire]] has named the Woodstock Film Festival among the top 50 independent film festivals worldwide.
'''The Regina International Film Festival and Awards (RIFFA)'''<ref name="riffa.ca">{{cite web|url=http://www.riffa.ca|title=Regina International Film Festival And Awards|website=www.riffa.ca}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/2157506/international-film-festival-coming-to-regina/|title=International Film Festival coming to Regina|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/saskatchewan/regina-international-film-festival-to-be-held-in-october-1.3185913|title=Regina International Film Festival to be held in October - CBC News|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="leaderpost.com">{{cite web|url=http://leaderpost.com/news/local-news/regina-set-to-compete-on-the-international-stage|title=Regina set to compete on the international stage|date=21 September 2015|publisher=}}</ref> founded by John Thimothy,<ref name="leaderpost.com"/> one of the top leading international film festivals in western Canada ([[Regina, Saskatchewan]]) represented 92 countries in 2015 festival . RIFFA annual Award show and red carpet arrival event is getting noticed in the contemporary film and fashion industries in [[Western Canada]].
Toronto's '''[[Hot Docs Canadian International Documentary Festival|Hot Docs]]''' founded by filmmaker Paul Jay, is the leading North American documentary film festival. Toronto also has the largest amount of film festivals in the world, ranging from cultural, independent, and historic films. The largest festival, in terms of the number of feature productions, is the [[Seattle International Film Festival]], which screens 270 features, and approximately 150 short films.{{Citation needed|date=October 2007}} The [[Whistler Film Festival]] gets bigger every year, with more than 80 screenings and an industry summit.
=== Latin American === The [[Cartagena Film Festival]], founded by [[Victor Nieto]] in 1960, is the oldest film festival in Latin America.<ref name=variety>{{cite news |first=Anna Marie|last=de la Fuente|title=Cartagena Festival's Nieto dies at 92, Director of oldest film festival in Latin America |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117996747.html?categoryId=25&cs=1|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=|date=2008-12-03 |accessdate=2008-12-07}}</ref> The [[Festival de Gramado]] (or Gramado Film Festival) [[Gramado]], [[Brazil]], along with the [[Guadalajara International Film Festival]] in [[Guadalajara]], the [[Morelia International Film Festival]] in Morelia, Michoacan [[Mexico]], and the [[Los Cabos International Film Festival]] founded by [[Scott Cross (film director)]], [[Sean Cross]], and Eduardo Sanchez Navarro, in [[Los Cabos]] [[Baja Sur]] [[Mexico]] are considered the most important film festivals of Latin America. In 2015, [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] called the [[Los Cabos International Film Festival]] the "Cannes of Latin America". The Huelva Ibero-American Film Festival has been held since 1975 in that Spanish city.
The [[Expresión en Corto International Film Festival]] is the largest competitive film festival in Mexico. It specializes in emerging talent, and is held in the last week of each July in the two colonial cities of [[San Miguel de Allende]] and [[Guanajuato]]. [[Oaxaca Film Fest]]. For Spanish-speaking countries, the [[Dominican International Film Festival]] takes place annually in Puerto Plata, Dominican Republic. The [[Valdivia International Film Festival]] is held annually in the city of [[Valdivia, Chile|Valdivia]]. It is arguable the most important film festival in [[Chile]].{{Citation needed|date=October 2007}} There is also Filmambiente, held in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, an international festival on environmental films and videos.
=== The Caribbean === The [[Havana Film Festival]] was founded in 1979 and is the oldest continuous annual film festival in the Caribbean. Its focus is on [[Latin American cinema]]. The [[Trinidad and Tobago Film Festival]], founded in 2006, is dedicated to screening the newest films from the English-, Spanish, French- and Dutch-speaking Caribbean, as well as the region's diaspora. It also seeks to facilitate the growth of Caribbean cinema by offering a wide-ranging industry programme and networking opportunities.
=== Animation === Many film festivals are dedicated exclusively to animation.
* [[Annecy International Animated Film Festival]] (f. 1960—the oldest) * [[Animafest Zagreb|Zagreb]] (f. 1972) * [[Ottawa International Animation Festival|Ottawa]] (f. 1976) * [[Hiroshima International Animation Festival|Hiroshima]] (f. 1985) * [[KROK International Animated Films Festival|KROK]] (f. 1989) * [[Anima Mundi (event)|Anima Mundi]] (f. 1992) * [[Animac]] (f. 1996)
A variety of regional festivals happen in various countries. [[Austin Film Festival]] is accredited by the [[Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences]], which makes all their jury award-winning narrative short and animated short films eligible for an Academy Award.
=== Asian film festivals === [[Delhi International Film Festival]] organised by '''The Social Circle''' (A society set up in 2011, to serve a cause, formed as a step towards inclusiveness, with the primary aim of creating social awareness, pursues the mission of holistic community development.) is a six-day event held at Delhi, in association with [[New Delhi Municipal Council]], [[Ministry of Information and Broadcasting (India)|Information & Broadcasting Ministry]] and Government of Delhi, supported by Ministry of culture and Ministry of Tourism. DIFF being one of its kind, has played an important role in the promotion of Indian Cinema, Art and Culture by organizing Indian programs in Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Afghanistan, Ukraine, Egypt, Tunisia, Jordan, Israel, USA and last year in association with the Information & Broadcasting Ministry and the Embassy of India in Morocco. This festival is hailed as one of the best Film Festivals in India, Asia and around the world.
Notable Asian film festivals include the '''[[Delhi International Film Festival]]''' organized in New Delhi annually ever since 2012, Osian's-Cinefan: Festival of Asian Cinema at New Delhi, which recently expanded to include Arab Cinema, and the Annual Mumbai Film Festival in India, with its 200,000 USD cash prize (www.mumbaifilmfest.com), Toronto Reel Asian International Film Festival, (www.reelasian.com), [[Mumbai Women's International Film Festival]] (MWIFF) is an annual film festival in Mumbai featuring films made by women directors and women technicians. and the [[Hong Kong International Film Festival]] ([[HKIFF]]), '''Chennai Women's International Film Festival''' ('''CWIFF''') and [[Busan International Film Festival]] (BIFF). [[International Film Festival of India]], the official International film festival organised by Government of India held at Goa every year is a famous film festival.<ref>{{cite web|author=IFFI|title=IFFi|url=http://www.iffi.nic.in/aboutus.asp|website=www.iffi.nic.in|accessdate=21 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140810105623/http://iffi.nic.in/aboutus.asp|archive-date=2014-08-10|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> [[International Film Festival of Kerala]] organised by Government of Kerala held at [[Thiruvananthapuram]] every year in the month of December is the biggest film festival in India in terms of public participation.<ref>{{cite web|author=IFFI|title=IFFI|url=http://www.iffk.in/index.php|website=www.iffk.in|accessdate=21 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140821233508/http://www.iffk.in/index.php|archive-date=21 August 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[International Documentary and Short Film Festival of Kerala]] (IDSFFK) hosted by the Kerala State Chalachitra Academy on behalf of Department of Cultural Affairs, Government of Kerala is a major documentary and short film festival.,<ref>{{cite web|title=IDSFFK|url=http://www.iffk.in/idsffk/home.php|website=www.iffk.in/idsffk|accessdate=21 August 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140821232719/http://www.iffk.in/idsffk/home.php|archivedate=21 August 2014|df=}}</ref> Kolkata International Film Festival at Kolkata in India, Rafi Peer International Film Festival at Lahore in Pakistan, Jagran Film Festival (JFF), Kolkata International Children's Film Festival and newly started Dehradun International Film Festival at Dehradun, Uttrakhand in India. And [[:it:All Lights India International Film Festival|All Lights India International Film Festival]]<ref>{{cite web|title=All lights india international film festival |url=http://aliiff.com/}}</ref> at Kochi. it is also newly started International Film Festival. Besides that there is Kathmandu International Mountain Film Festival [[Kathmandu International Mountain Film Festival]] organized every year at the capital city of Nepal and the heart of the Himalayas.
=== African festivals === There are several significant film festivals held regularly in Africa. The biannual [[Panafrican Film and Television Festival of Ouagadougou]] (FESPACO) in [[Burkina Faso]] was established in 1969 and accepts for competition only films by African filmmakers and chiefly produced in Africa. The annual [[Durban International Film Festival]] in [[South Africa]] and [[Zanzibar International Film Festival]] in [[Tanzania]] have grown in importance for the film and entertainment industry, as they often screen the African premieres of many international films.
The [[Sahara International Film Festival]], held annually in the [[Sahrawi refugee camps]] in western Algeria near the border of [[Western Sahara]], is notable as the only film festival in the world to take place in a refugee camp. The festival has the two-fold aim of providing cultural entertainment and educational opportunities to refugees, and of raising awareness of the plight of the Sahrawi people, who have been exiled from their native Western Sahara for more than three decades.
=== European festivals === {{further|List of film festivals in Europe}} The biggest European festival is the Cannes Film Festival in France along with the Berlin and Venice film festivals.

[[File:Hans Holbein the Younger - Mary, Lady Guildford (Saint Louis Art Museum).JPG|right|thumb|250px|Mary Wotton, Lady Guildenford, wearing a gable hood with pinned up [[lappet]]s and a hanging veil. [[Hans Holbein the Younger]], 1527.]] A '''gable hood''', '''English hood''' or '''gable headdress''' is an [[England|English]] woman's [[hat|headdress]] of {{circa|1500–1550}}, so-called because its pointed shape resembles the [[gable]] of a house. The contemporary [[French hood]] was rounded in outline and unlike the gable hood, less conservative, displaying the front part of the hair.
Originally a simple pointed hood with decorated side panels called ''[[lappet]]s'' and a veil at the back, over time the gable hood became a complex construction stiffened with [[buckram]], with a box-shaped back and two tube-shaped hanging veils at 90-degree angles; the hanging veils and lappets could be pinned up in a variety of ways to make complex headdresses.
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Elizabeth of York from Kings and Queens of England.jpg|Early gable hood: [[Elizabeth of York]] {{circa|1500}} File:Gablehood front-back c1535 detail.jpg|Front and back views of a box-backed gable hood of {{circa|lk=no|1528–30}}. Detail of a drawing by Holbein File:Holbein gable hood eng.jpg|Gable hood with lappets and one side of veil pinned up (engraving after Holbein {{circa|lk=no|1535}}) File:Hans Holbein d. J. 033.jpg|Gable hood of {{circa|lk=no|1543}} </gallery>
==See also== * [[1500–1550 in Western European fashion]] * [[Catherine of Aragon]] * [[Jane Seymour]] * [[Mary Boleyn]]
==References== * Ashelford, Jane: ''The Art of Dress: Clothing and Society 1500–1914'', Abrams, 1996. {{ISBN|0-8109-6317-5}} * Ashelford, Jane: ''A Visual History of Costume: The Sixteenth Century'', Drama Books, 1983. {{ISBN|0-89676-076-6}}
==External links== {{Commons|Gable hood}} * [http://www.uvm.edu/~hag/sca/tudor/gable.html Tudor Gable Headdress: A Portfolio of Images] * [http://www.elizabethancostume.net/headwear/coif.html Tudor and Elizabethan Coifs]

{{infobox military award | name = Gerhard Herzberg Canada Gold Medal for Science and Engineering | image = | caption = | awarded_by = [[Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council]] | country = [[Canada]] | type = | eligibility = | for = | campaign = | status = | description = | motto = | clasps = | post-nominals = | established = | first_award = | last_award = | total = | posthumous = | recipients = | precedence_label = | individual = | higher = | same = | lower = | related = | image2 = | caption2 = }} The '''Gerhard Herzberg Canada Gold Medal for Science and Engineering''' is awarded by the [[Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council]] (NSERC) of Canada to recognize "research contributions characterized by both excellence and influence."{{cite web|title=NSERC - Gerhard Herzberg - About the Award|url=http://www.nserc-crsng.gc.ca/Prizes-Prix/Herzberg-Herzberg/About-Apropos_eng.asp|publisher=[[Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council]]|accessdate=2011-01-01}} Prior to 2000, NSERC had awarded the '''Canada Gold Medal for Science and Engineering''', before deciding to rename the award to honour [[Gerhard Herzberg]], winner of the 1971 [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry]].{{cite news|title=Finalists for Canada's Top Science Prize Announced|publisher=Canada News Wire|location=Ottawa|date=2004-11-17|page=1}} The Herzberg medal is commonly called Canada's top award for science and engineering.{{cite web|title=Ottawa scientist honoured with $1M prize|url=http://www.cbc.ca/technology/story/2009/03/17/ot-090317-scientist.html|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcast Corporation]]|date=2009-03-17|accessdate=2011-01-02}}{{cite web|title=Dr. Howard Alper Reappointed as Chair of the Science, Technology and Innovation Council|url=http://www.exchangemagazine.com/morningpost/2010/week51/Monday/122002.htm|work=Exchange Magazine|date=2010-12-20|accessdate=2011-01-02}} It is an individual annual award that recognizes continued excellence and influence in research in either natural sciences or engineering.{{cite web|title=NSERC - Gerhard Herzberg - About the Award|url=http://www.nserc-crsng.gc.ca/Prizes-Prix/Herzberg-Herzberg/About-Apropos_eng.asp|publisher=[[Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council]]|accessdate=2011-01-02}} The award is a gold medal, and the guarantee of $1 million over five years to use for personal research. ==About the award== NSERC's Canada Gold Medal for Science and Engineering was first awarded in 1991 to [[Raymond Lemieux]], a [[chemist]] working at [[University of Alberta]].{{cite web|title=Past Winners|url=http://www.nserc-crsng.gc.ca/Prizes-Prix/Herzberg-Herzberg/Past-Anciens_eng.asp?Year=1993|publisher=[[Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council]]|accessdate=2011-01-02}} Mathematician [[James Arthur (mathematician)|James Arthur]] from the [[University of Toronto]] was the 1999 recipient,{{cite web|title=Past Winners|url=http://www.nserc-crsng.gc.ca/Prizes-Prix/Herzberg-Herzberg/Past-Anciens_eng.asp?Year=1999|publisher=[[Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council]]|accessdate=2011-01-02}} the last year before the award was renamed in honour of [[Gerhard Herzberg]], the winner of the 1971 [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry]]. NSERC decided to rename the award after Herzberg because they felt he embodied the two main qualities of the award, namely research contributions that are of high quality and influential. The Herzberg medal is awarded to a scientist or engineer working at a facility in Canada. It is considered Canada's top award for science and engineering. Eligible facilities include universities, government and private labs. Nominations can be submitted by any Canadian citizen or permanent resident. The winner is chosen by a selection committee representing different scientific disciplines, who make a recommendations to the current NSERC president.{{cite web|title=NSERC - Gerhard Herzberg - Call for nominations|url=http://www.nserc-crsng.gc.ca/Prizes-Prix/Herzberg-Herzberg/Nomination-Nomination_eng.asp|publisher=[[Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council]]|accessdate=2011-01-08}} The award consists of a gold medal, and the guarantee of at least $1 million to use for research or for establishing research chairs, fellowships or scholarships in the recipients' name. ==Recipients== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Recipient ! Affiliation ! The other two finalists (if it was their first time as a finalist) were awarded NSERC's Award of Excellence.{{cite web|title=NSERC - Award of Excellence|url=http://www.nserc-crsng.gc.ca/Prizes-Prix/Excellence-Excellence/Index-Index_eng.asp|publisher=[[Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council]]|accessdate=2011-01-08}} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Science and technology awards]] [[Category:Awards established in 1993]]

{{unref|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox song | name = Gitarzan | cover = | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Ray Stevens]] | album = [[Gitarzan (album)|Gitarzan]] | B-side = Bagpipes - That's My Bag | released = January 6, 1969 | format = 45 rpm vinyl | recorded = | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Pop music|Pop]] | length = 3:15
3:00 (7" version) | label = [[Monument Records|Monument]] | writer = Ray Stevens, Bill Everette | producer = Fred Foster, Ray Stevens, Jim Malloy | prev_title = The Great Escape | prev_year = 1968 | next_title = [[Along Came Jones (song)|Along Came Jones]] | next_year = 1969 }} '''"Gitarzan"''' is a [[novelty song]] released by [[Ray Stevens]] in 1969 about a character who lives in a jungle and forms a musical band with his female partner, [[Jane Porter (Tarzan)|Jane]], and their [[pet monkey]]. The song features [[Tarzan]]'s jungle calls, scat singing, and a funky [[boogie-woogie]], as well as a quote from the song "[[Swinging on a Star]]", with the line "Carrying noonbeams home in a jar" sung with the wrong notes. The song reached #8 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] in April 1969, and #10 in Canada in May 1969. The music and lyrics were written by Stevens with a title supplied by [[Bill Justis]]. Justis is officially credited as Bill Everette. ==Cover versions== A cover version was recorded by [[country music]] [[parodist]] [[Cledus T. Judd]] on his tribute album ''[[Boogity, Boogity - A Tribute to the Comedic Genius of Ray Stevens]]'' in 2007. Judd's cover features [[Keith Urban]] and [[Heidi Newfield]] (former lead singer of [[Trick Pony]]). An earlier cover appeared on [[Ralph's World]]'s ''Green Gorilla, Monster and Me!'' (a children's music album) in 2006. ==External links== * {{MetroLyrics song|ray-stevens|gitarzan}} {{Ray Stevens}} {{Tarzan}} [[Category:1969 singles]] [[Category:Novelty songs]] [[Category:Ray Stevens songs]] [[Category:Cledus T. {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{italic title}} [[File:Korean traditional shoes-01.jpg|thumb|alt=A pair of low, red women's shoes and a pair of black boots on a step|''Hye'' (foreground) and ''hwa'' (background)]] '''''Hwahyejang ''''' ({{korean|hangul=화혜장}}) are craftsmen who construct traditional [[Korea]]n footwear. The shoes are classified into ''hwa'' (shoes that go over the ankle) and ''hye'' (shoes that do not cover the ankle), hence the compound word "''hwahyejang''".<ref name=CHAK>{{cite web|title=Hwahyejang|url=http://jikimi.cha.go.kr/english/search_plaza_new/EMapResultView.jsp?VdkVgwKey=17,01160000,11&strGuCode=28&strSidoCode=11|work=Heritage Information|publisher=Cultural Heritage Administration of Korea|accessdate=8 April 2013}}</ref> Historically, the two distinct types of shoe were made by separate specialist craftsmen, the ''hyejang'' and the ''hwajang''.<ref name=koreana>{{cite web|last=Park|first=Hyun Sook|title=Shoemaker Hwang Hae-bong|url=http://www.koreana.or.kr/months/news_view.asp?b_idx=533&lang=en&page_type=list|work=Koreana|publisher=Korea Foundation|accessdate=10 April 2013}}</ref>
==Hwang Hae-bong== The only surviving traditional ''hwahyejang'' in Korea today is Hwang Hae-bong, who operates a small workshop in [[Seoul]]. His family have been making shoes for five generations. Hwang learned the trade from his grandfather and is training his second son Hwang Deok-jin to continue in the profession. In 2004, at the age of sixty, Hwang was recognised by Korea's Cultural Heritage Association as an intangible cultural asset, following in the footsteps of his grandfather Hwang Han-gap, who was made a cultural asset in 1971.<ref name=koreana/><ref name=joongang2>{{cite web|last=Lee|first=Ho-jeong|title=There's no business like shoe business|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2882884|work=Korea Joongang Daily|publisher=Joongang Ilbo|accessdate=8 April 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120709201951/http://koreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2882884|archivedate=9 July 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=joongang>{{cite web|last=Lee |first=Yeong-hee |title=Traditional shoes wear thin, but last hwahyejang carries on |url=http://en.korea.com/blog/handb/beauty-fashion/traditional-shoes-wear-thin-but-last-hwahyejang-carries-on/ |work=Korea Joongang Daily |publisher=JoongAng Ilbo |accessdate=8 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120623072950/http://en.korea.com/blog/handb/beauty-fashion/traditional-shoes-wear-thin-but-last-hwahyejang-carries-on/ |archivedate=23 June 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Traditional shoes represent Korean beauty, elegance |url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/art/2011/04/135_85554.html |publisher=Korea Times |accessdate=10 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140810082958/http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/art/2011/04/135_85554.html |archivedate=10 August 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==History== The basic form of the Korean shoe was developed during the [[Three Kingdoms of Korea|Three Kingdoms era]], although earlier forms date back to prehistoric times.<ref name=koreana/> During the early [[Joseon|Joseon period]] as many as 30 professional shoemakers were employed at court. The shoemaking caste, however, was considered ''[[cheonmin]]'', the lowest possible caste. At this time, shoes were an important indicator of a person's profession or social status, with designs, colours and styles varying depending on social caste or occupation.<ref name=arirang>{{cite web|title=Hwahye; Korean Shoes|url=http://www.arirang.co.kr/Tv2/ALegacy_Archive.asp?PROG_CODE=tvcr0301&view_cont_seq=24&code=St1&sys_lang=Eng|work=Ancestral Legacies|publisher=Arirang|accessdate=8 April 2013}}</ref> However, after the [[Gabo Reform]] of 1894, traditional leather shoes became less popular, and in the twentieth century were largely superseded by rubber ''[[gomusin]]''.
Since the release of [[Kim Yong-ik]]'s short story ''Wedding Shoes'' and the film ''[[Flower Shoes|Ggotsin]]'' ("flower shoes") the term ''ggotsin'' has become a popular alternative name for classical Korean shoes.<ref name="joongang2"/><ref name="joongang"/> ''Hwahye'' are still worn for special occasions such as royal weddings, and for days of national mourning.<ref name=arirang/> In 2004 the art of shoemaking was recognised as an [[Important Intangible Cultural Properties of Korea|Important Intangible Cultural Property of Korea]].<ref name=CHAK/><ref name=UNESCO>{{cite web|title=Hwahyejang |url=http://www.ichcap.org/en/archives/unescoView2.jsp?ich_name=ICH_LIST3_ENG&idx=&listLIDX=126&searchtext= |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130704023441/http://www.ichcap.org/en/archives/unescoView2.jsp?ich_name=ICH_LIST3_ENG&idx=&listLIDX=126&searchtext= |dead-url=yes |archive-date=4 July 2013 |work=ICH Archives |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=8 April 2013 }}</ref>
==Construction== It can take as much as a week to craft a single pair of shoes.<ref name=joongang/> The shoes are typically made from leather obtained from cows, pigs or sheep, although historically horsehide and deerskin were also used. Whereas Western shoes are shaped differently for left and right feet, Korean shoes are identical for both feet; the softness of the leather gradually conforms to the shape of the owner's foot. Some types have ribbons or laces that are knotted around the ankle to keep the shoe in place. Many are decorated with floral designs, and are sometimes covered with an ornamental silk upper.<ref name=CHAK/><ref name=joongang2/>
The process of creating a traditional shoe involves up to 72 individual processes, the most important of which is the stitching. This is performed using a needle made from a boar bristle, rather than a manufactured steel needle, due to the need for flexibility.<ref name=koreana/>
==Styles== The following table shows the main types of traditional Korean shoe made by the ''hwahyejang'':<ref name=joongang2/>
{| border="1" class="wikitable" |+ Shoe types ! Name ! Features ! Use |- ! Jeokseok | Red, secured by ankle ribbons | Worn by the king for official and ritual occasions |- ! Taesahye | Silk or sheepskin upper, leather sole. High, wide toe with white lines. | Everyday shoe for men |- ! Balmakhye | Black or grey | Used by the elderly or infirm |- ! Woekohye | Dyed black or grey silk, patterned toe | General use |- ! Yuhye | Waterproofed using [[Perilla frutescens|perilla oil]], sole affixed with [[Wiktionary:clout-nail|clout nails]] | Wet weather shoe |- ! Baekhye | White | Mourning shoe worn after a king's death by the general populance |- ! Onhye | Quilted lining | Winter footwear |- ! Jaehye | Short ribbons attached which are tied for a secure fit | Ceremonial and ritual use |- ! Hwaja | Black and unadorned, with a leather or wooden sole and a woollen upper | Worn by court officials on palace business |- ! Baekmokhwa | Undecorated | Mourning shoe worn after a king's death by court officials |- ! Cheongseok | Blue with ankle ribbons | Worn by the queen |- ! Danghye | Patterned silk | Worn by upper-class women |- ! Unhye | Silk with a cloud pattern | Worn by upper-class women |- ! Soohye | Silk embroidered with flowers | Also called ''ggotsin'' |- ! Gihye | Black silk or leather | Worn by [[kisaeng]] |}

{{Infobox film | name = Jiggs and Maggie | image = | image size = | caption = Joe Yule, George McManus, and Rene Riano | director = | producer = | writer = Based on the cartoons of [[George McManus]] | narrator = | starring = [[Joe Yule]]
[[Renie Riano]] | music = | cinematography = | editing = | studio = [[Monogram Pictures]] | distributor = Monogram Pictures | released = 1946-1950 | runtime = | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | website = }}'''Jiggs and Maggie''' were the major characters in a series of films made by the American studio [[Monogram Pictures]] between 1946 and 1950. Jiggs and Maggie are [[Irish people|Irish]] immigrants to the [[United States]], who constantly argue. The characters were created by the cartoonist [[George McManus]] in his long-running strip ''[[Bringing Up Father]]''.Drew p.170 McManus appears in four of the films, playing himself. The characters had first appeared on screen in the 1928 [[MGM]] film ''[[Bringing Up Father (1928 film)|Bringing Up Father]]''. In 1946 Monogram made a fresh version starring actors [[Joe Yule]] and [[Renie Riano]]. Due to the popularity of the film, a series of four spin-offs were made. Monogram was a low-budget studio that specializes in making comedy, crime and western series. The final film in the series, ''[[Jiggs and Maggie Out West]]'', was released a little less than a month after Yule suffered a fatal heart attack. ==Films== * ''[[Bringing Up Father (1946 film)|Bringing Up Father]]'' (1946) * ''[[Jiggs and Maggie in Society]]'' (1947) * ''[[Jiggs and Maggie in Court]]'' (1948) * ''[[Jiggs and Maggie in Jackpot Jitters]]'' (1949) * ''[[Jiggs and Maggie Out West]]'' (1950) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== * Drew, Bernard. ''Motion Picture Series and Sequels: A Reference Guide''. Routledge, 2013. '''Knowledge sharing''' is an activity through which [[knowledge]] (namely, information, skills, or expertise) is exchanged among people, friends, families, communities (for example, Wikipedia), or organizations.<ref name=2KMF>{{cite book|last1=Bukowitz|last2=Williams|first1=Wendi R.|first2=Ruth L.|title=The Knowledge Management Fieldbook|year=1999|publisher=FT Press|isbn=978-0273638827}}</ref><ref name=5OKM>{{cite web|last1=Serban|last2=Luan|first1=Andreea M.|first2=Jing (2002)|title=An Overview of Knowledge Management|url=http://www.uky.edu/~gmswan3/575/Serban_and_Luan_2002.pdf|publisher=University of Kentucky|accessdate=17 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hasmath|first=Reza|last2=Hsu|first2=Jennifer Y. J.|date=2016|title=Communities of Practice and the NGO Sector in China|ssrn=2612686|journal=|location=|publisher=International Society for Third Sector Research Conference (Stockholm, Sweden), June 28-July 1|volume=|page=1}}</ref>
Organizations have recognized that knowledge constitutes a valuable [[intangible asset]] for creating and sustaining competitive advantages.<ref name=6AMJ /> Knowledge sharing activities are generally supported by [[knowledge management system]]s.<ref name="15BF">{{cite web|url=http://www.crunchbase.com/company/bloomfire|title=Bloomfire|work=CrunchBase|accessdate=17 April 2013}}</ref> However, technology constitutes only one of the many factors that affect the sharing of knowledge in organizations, such as [[organizational culture]], [[Trust (social sciences)|trust]], and [[incentives]].<ref name="Cabrera">{{cite journal|last=Cabrera|first=A.|author2=Cabrera, E. F.|year=2002|title=Knowledge-sharing Dilemmas|journal=Organization Studies|volume=23|issue=5|pages=687–710|doi=10.1177/0170840602235001}}</ref> The sharing of knowledge constitutes a major challenge in the field of [[knowledge management]] because some employees tend to resist sharing their knowledge with the rest of the organization.<ref name="Patriota">{{cite journal|last=Ciborra|first=C.U.|author2=Patriota, G.|year=1998|title=Groupware and teamwork in R&D: limits to learning and innovation|journal=R&D Management|volume=28|issue=1|pages=1–10}}</ref>
In the digital world, websites and applications enable knowledge or talent sharing between individuals and/or within teams. The individuals can easily reach the people who want to learn, share their talent and get rewarded.
==Flow or transfer== Although knowledge is commonly treated as an object, [[Dave Snowden]] has argued it is more appropriate to teach it as both a flow and a thing.<ref name="Snowden">{{cite journal | title = Complex acts of knowing: paradox and descriptive self-awareness| last = Snowden | first = D. | year = 2002| journal = Journal of Knowledge Management | pages = 100–111 | volume = 6 | issue = 2 | doi = 10.1108/13673270210424639}}</ref> Knowledge as a flow can be related to the concept of tacit knowledge,<ref name="Polanyi">{{cite book | title = Personal Knowledge: Towards a Post-Critical Philosophy | last = Polanyi | first = M. | year = 2003 | origyear = 1958 | publisher = CRC Press | isbn = 0-203-44215-6 | pages = 428}}</ref><ref name="Nonaka">{{cite journal | title = A dynamic theory of organizational knowledge creation | last = Nonaka | first = I. | year = 1994 | journal = Organization Science | pages = 14–37 | volume = 5 | issue = 1 | doi = 10.1287/orsc.5.1.14| jstor = 2635068}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | title = Tacit Knowledge and Knowledge Conversion: Controversy and Advancement in Organizational Knowledge Creation Theory | last = Nonaka | first = I. | year = 2009 | journal = Organization Science | volume = 20 | issue = 3 | url = http://zonecours.hec.ca/documents/H2010-1-2241390.S2-TacitKnowledgeandKnowledgeConversion-ControversyandAdvancementinOrganizationalKnowledgeCreation.pdf | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20101122050857/http://zonecours.hec.ca/documents/H2010-1-2241390.S2-TacitKnowledgeandKnowledgeConversion-ControversyandAdvancementinOrganizationalKnowledgeCreation.pdf | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 2010-11-22 | pages = 635–652 | doi = 10.1287/orsc.1080.0412 }}</ref> While the difficulty of sharing knowledge is in transferring knowledge from one entity to another,<ref>{{Cite journal | title = Knowledge Transfer: A Basis for Competitive Advantage in Firms | year = 2000 | journal = Organizational Behavior and Human Decision Processes | pages = 150–169 | volume = 82 | issue = 1 | doi = 10.1006/obhd.2000.2893 | last1 = Argote | first1 = L. | last2 = Ingram | first2 = P. | postscript = <!--None-->}}</ref><ref name=Fan1998>{{Cite journal | title = The Transfer of Western Management to China: Context, Content and Constraints | year = 1998 | author = Fan, Y. | journal = Management Learning | pages = 201–221 | volume = 29 | issue = 2 | doi = 10.1177/1350507698292005 | postscript = <!--None-->}}</ref> it may prove profitable for organizations to acknowledge the difficulties of [[knowledge transfer]], adopting new knowledge management strategies accordingly.<ref name="Snowden" />
==Explicit knowledge==
[[Explicit knowledge]] sharing occurs when explicit knowledge is made available to be shared between entities. Explicit knowledge sharing can happen successfully when the following criteria are met: * Articulation: the knowledge provider can describe the information.<ref name=2KMF /> * Awareness: the recipient must be aware that knowledge is available.<ref name=2KMF /> * Access: the knowledge recipient can access the knowledge provider.<ref name=2KMF /> * Guidance: the body of knowledge must be defined and differentiated into different topics or domains so as to avoid information overload, and to provide easy access to appropriate material. Knowledge managers are often considered key figures in the creation of an effective knowledge sharing system.<ref name=2KMF /><ref name=3HBS>{{cite book|last1=Prusak|first1=Lawrence|last2=Davenport|first2=Thomas H.|title=Working Knowledge: How Organizations Manage What They Know, 2nd Edition|year=2000|publisher=Harvard Business School Press|location=Cambridge, MA|isbn=1-57851-301-4}}</ref> * Completeness: the [[holistic]] approach to knowledge sharing in the form of both centrally managed and self-published knowledge.
==Tacit knowledge==
[[Tacit knowledge]] sharing occurs through different types of socialization. Although tacit knowledge is difficult to identify and codify, relevant factors that influence tacit knowledge sharing include: * Informal networks such as daily interactions between people within a defined environment (work, school, home, etc.). These networks span [[hierarchies]] and functions.<ref name=3HBS /> * The provision of space where people can engage in unstructured or unmonitored discussions, thereby fostering informal networks.<ref name=3HBS /> * Unstructured, less-structured or experimental work practices that encourage [[creative problem solving]], and the development of [[social network]]s.<ref name=3HBS />
==Embedded knowledge==
Embedded knowledge sharing occurs when knowledge is shared through clearly delineated products, processes, routines, etc. This knowledge can be shared in different ways, such as: * [[Scenario planning]] and [[debriefing]]: providing a structured space to create possible scenarios, followed by a discussion of what happened, and how it could have been different.<ref name=4UKY>{{cite web|last1=Serban|last2=Luan|first1=Andreea M.|first2=Jing (2002)|title=Corporate Strategy Model: Scenario Planning|url=http://www.uky.edu/~gmswan3/575/Serban_and_Luan_2002.pdf|publisher=University of Kentucky|accessdate=17 April 2013}}</ref> * Management training. * Knowledge transfer: deliberately integrating systems, processes, routines, etc., to combine and share relevant knowledge.
==Importance to organizations== Knowledge constitutes a valuable, intangible asset for creating and sustaining competitive advantages within organizations.<ref name=6AMJ>{{cite journal|last=Miller|first=D.|author2=Shamsie, J. |title=The resource-based view of the firm in two environments: The Hollywood film studios from 1936 to 1965|journal=Academy of Management Journal|year=1996|volume=39|issue=5|pages=519–543|doi=10.2307/256654|jstor = 256654}}<!--|accessdate=17 April 2013--></ref> Several factors affect knowledge sharing in organizations, such as organizational culture, trust, incentives, and technology.<ref name=7OS>{{cite journal|last=Cabrera|first=A.|author2=Cabrera, C. |title=Knowledge-sharing Dilemmas|journal=Organization Studies|year=2002|volume=23|issue=5|pages=687–710|doi=10.1177/0170840602235001}}<!--|accessdate=17 April 2013--></ref> Knowledge sharing activities are commonly supported by [[knowledge management]] systems, a form of [[information technology]] (IT) that facilitates and organizes information within a company or organization.<ref name=13KMM>{{cite journal|last=Gurteen|first=David|title=Creating a knowledge sharing culture|journal=Knowledge Management Magazine|date=February 1999|volume=2|issue=5|accessdate=}}</ref>
==Challenges== Knowledge sharing can sometimes constitute a major challenge in the field of knowledge management.<ref name=Nonaka /> The difficulty of knowledge sharing resides in the transference of knowledge from one entity to another.<ref name=Fan1998 /><ref name=11AI>{{cite journal|last=Argote|first=L.|author2=Ingram, P. |title=Knowledge Transfer: A Basis for Competitive Advantage in Firms|journal=Organizational Behavior and Human Decision Processes|year=2000|volume=82|issue=1|pages=150–169|doi=10.1006/obhd.2000.2893}}<!--|accessdate=17 April 2013--></ref> Some employees tend to resist sharing their knowledge<ref name=Nonaka /> because of the notion that knowledge is property; ownership, therefore, becomes very important.<ref name=10Dal>{{cite book|last=Dalkir|first=K.|title=Knowledge Management In Theory And Practice|year=2005|publisher=Jordan Hill|location=Oxford: Elsevier Inc|pages=132–133}}</ref> In order to counteract this, individuals must be reassured that they will receive some type of incentive for what they create.<ref name=10Dal /> However, Dalkir (2005) demonstrated that individuals are most commonly rewarded for what they know, not what they share.<ref name=10Dal /> Negative consequences, such as isolation and resistance to ideas, occur when knowledge sharing is impeded.<ref name=13KMM /> To promote knowledge sharing and remove knowledge sharing obstacles, the organizational culture of an entity should encourage discovery and innovation.<ref name=10Dal /> Members who trust each other are willing to exchange knowledge and at the same time want to embrace knowledge from other members as well. <ref>Levin, D.Z. & Cross, R. (2004). The Strength of Weak Ties You Can Trust: The Mediating Role of Trust in Effective Knowledge Transfer. Management Science, Vol. 50, No. 11.</ref>
==Connection to information technology systems== Information technology (IT) systems are common tools that help facilitate knowledge sharing and knowledge management.<ref name=13KMM /><!-- <ref name=14AKFT /> --> The main role of IT systems is to help people share knowledge through common platforms and [[electronic storage]] to help make access simpler, encouraging economic reuse of knowledge.<!-- <ref name=14AKFT /> --> IT systems can provide codification, personalization, electronic repositories for information and can help people locate each other to communicate directly.<!-- <ref name=14AKFT /> --> With appropriate training and education, IT systems can make it easier for organizations to acquire, store or disseminate knowledge.<ref name=13KMM /><!-- <ref name=14AKFT /> -->
==Economic theory== In economic theory, knowledge sharing has been studied in the field of industrial organization and in the field of contract theory. In [[industrial organization]], Bhattacharya, Glazer, and Sappington (1992) have emphasized the importance of knowledge sharing in research joint ventures in a context of imperfect competition.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bhattacharya|first=Sudipto|last2=Glazer|first2=Jacob|last3=Sappington|first3=David E.M|date=1992|title=Licensing and the sharing of knowledge in research joint ventures|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/0022-0531(92)90068-S|journal=Journal of Economic Theory|volume=56|issue=1|pages=43–69|doi=10.1016/0022-0531(92)90068-s|issn=0022-0531|via=}}</ref> In the theory of [[incomplete contracts]], Rosenkranz and Schmitz (1999, 2003) have used the Grossman-Hart-Moore property rights approach to study how knowledge sharing is affected by the underlying ownership structure.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rosenkranz|first=Stephanie|last2=Schmitz|first2=Patrick W.|date=1999|title=Know-how disclosure and incomplete contracts|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/S0165-1765(99)00038-5|journal=Economics Letters|volume=63|issue=2|pages=181–185|doi=10.1016/s0165-1765(99)00038-5|issn=0165-1765|via=}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rosenkranz|first=Stephanie|last2=Schmitz|first2=Patrick W.|date=2003|title=Optimal allocation of ownership rights in dynamic R&D alliances|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/S0899-8256(02)00553-5|journal=Games and Economic Behavior|volume=43|issue=1|pages=153–173|doi=10.1016/s0899-8256(02)00553-5|issn=0899-8256|via=}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Collective intelligence]] * [[Community of practice]] * [[Knowledge market]] * [[Knowledge translation]]

{{Infobox occupation | name = Kulam | synonyms = | pronounce = | image = | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | official_names = Mangkukulam | type = [[Warlock]]/[[witch]] | activity_sector = [[Philippines]] | competencies = | formation = | employment_field = | related_occupation = [[Witch]] }}
'''Kulam''' or "Pagkukulam" is a form of [[folk magic]], specifically natural magic, practiced in the [[Philippines]]. It puts emphasis on the innate power of the self and a secret knowledge of ''Magica Baja'' or ''low magic''. Earth (soil), fire, herbs, spices, candles, oils and kitchenwares and utensils are often used for rituals, charms, spells and potions.
==Usage and related terms==
'''Mangkukulam''' (noun) is a person employing or using Kulam, ie the "witch".
'''Kinukulam''' (noun) is the target of the Kulam.
'''Nakulam''' (adj.) describes someone or something experiencing the effects of the Kulam.
'''Kulamin''' (verb) means to bewitch or do magic on a thing or person.
'''Ipakulam''' (verb) means to have someone bewitch, bless or hex someone or something else.
==Places== Kulam in the [[Philippines]] is said to be centered on the islands of [[Pampanga]] and [[Talalora, Samar|Talalora]], [[Samar|Western Samar]] and the province of [[Sorsogon]], where many of the country's [[faith healing|faith healers]] reside. Kulam also exists in many of the hinterlands, especially in Samar and Leyte.
However, Kulam itself is known and occurs anywhere on the Philippines.
==''Mangkukulam''== The '''Mangkukulam''' (/mahng-koo-KOO-lam/) can be considered a Filipino witch, literally meaning "a practitioner of ''kulam''". Other terms are the [[Spanish language in the Philippines|Spanish]] ''brujo'' and ''bruja'' (masculine and feminine forms of "witch"; Filipinized as ''bruho'' and ''bruha''). The verb '''kulamin''' (/koo-LAH-min/) means "to bless or hex", while a curse is called a ''sumpâ'' (/soom-PA/), which can also be translated as a "vow" or "oath". The ''' Mangkukulam ''' may use a voodoo doll and a needle to cast spells on people they want to revenge on, but largely use natural magic and superstitions similar to an [[Arbularyo|Albularyo]], or ''witch doctor''. Both can be considered witches, but the main difference is that the ''Albularyo'' is more of a doctor who heals people, while a ''Mangkukulam'' is a malevolent person who tricks and curses others.
To date, there have been no media, research, or claims that "good ''mangkukulam''" exist, so it is fair to assume that the ''mangkukulam'' is the "bad witch" of Philippine witchcraft.
== Curses and remedies == The primary methods employed by a ''mangkukulam'' are candle lighting ritual, scrying or tawas, recitation of spells, and concocting potions. Modern popular culture also depicts the ''mangkukulam'' as using either photographs or the equivalent of a [[Voodoo doll]]. Modern popular culture also depicts ''mangkukulam'' as mainly only doing love potions and malicious curses, but more extreme depictions claim they can summon ghosts to haunt dolls, raise the dead (or at least control dead bodies), and other things related to necromancy.
A typical belief of ''mangkukulam'' is that curses are mitigated by finding the caster and bribing them to lift the curse. [[Superstition|Superstitious]] people still attribute certain illnesses or diseases to ''kulam''. This most often happens in rural areas, where an herbal doctor called an ''[[Arbularyo|Albularyo]]'' (/al-boo-LAR-yoh/), diagnoses a victim using a [[divination]] method called ''pagtatawas'' and helps the victim cure their malady.
Darker forms of remedies to kulam include Albularyos whipping the bewitched person with a '''Buntot Pagi''' (Stingray's Tail) until the afflicted is forced to divulge the witch's name and confronting them. This is done in the belief that the one who is getting hurt is the witch and not the bewitched.

{{short description|1430s painting by Fra Angelico}} {{Infobox Artwork | image_file= Virgen humildad-fra angelico.jpg | image_size= 350px | title= Madonna of Humility | artist= Fra Angelico | year= 1433–1435 | medium= Tempera on wood | height_metric= 147 | width_metric= 91 | height_imperial= | width_imperial= | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=[[Barcelona]] | museum=[[Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya]] }} The '''''Madonna of Humility''''' is a painting by [[Fra Angelico]] which belongs to the [[Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum]] in [[Madrid]] and is conserved on loan at the [[National Art Museum of Catalonia]].<ref>Guide of the Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya. MNAC, 2004. {{ISBN|84-8043-136-9}}</ref>
== Description == The Virgin seated on a cushion placed directly on the ground with the child standing on her lap, holds a vase in her left hand which contains roses and a lily, symbols of motherhood and purity. The Child, who is also holding a lily, rests his forehead on his mother's cheek. They are set under a cloth of honour made of gold and black embroidered brocade held by three angels, while two more angels are seated on the ground playing an organ and a lute. The monumental figures, the splendour of the clothes, the modulated light and the use of the blue colour place this panel in the purest fifteenth-century Italian style. The work has been identified as the one described by [[Giorgio Vasari]] in 1568 in the home of the [[Gondi family]], in [[Florence]], where it formed part of a polyptic.<ref>[http://art.mnac.cat/fitxatecnica.html;jsessionid=47ebcd8e6d370c6926ffc938f57f3dd871295ffedac166160908977bcfde952b?inventoryNumber=212817-000 The artwork at MNAC's Website]</ref>

{{Infobox comic book title| | title = Marville | image = Marville (comics) 1.jpg | caption = Cover of Marville #1
Art by [[M. D. Bright|Mark D. Bright]] | schedule = | format = [[Limited series (comics)|Limited series]] |ongoing= |Superhero = | publisher = [[Marvel Comics]] | date = 2002–2003 | issues = 7 | main_char_team = | writers = [[Bill Jemas]] | artists = | editors = | pencillers = | inkers = | colorists = | creative_team_month = | creative_team_year = | creators = |subcat= |sort= }} '''''Marville''''' is a 2002 [[comic book]] [[Limited series (comics)|limited series]] published by [[Marvel Comics]]. The series was written by [[Bill Jemas]], and the stories involve satirical comments on comic book industry conventions and trends.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=npIsZV7grboC&pg=PA144&dq=marville+comics&hl=en&sa=X&ei=r90cUZvmNOmKiAK5t4C4Ag&ved=0CE0Q6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=marville&f=false |title=Marvel Graphic Novels and Related Publications: An Annotated Guide to Comics ... - Robert G. Weiner - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date=2008-03-17 |accessdate=2015-05-20}} The book is regularly considered one of the worst comics of all time due to its confusing and rapidly-changing plots as well as its blatantly promotional nature. ==Overview== The main character is Kal-[[AOL]] Turner, the son of [[Ted Turner]] and [[Jane Fonda]] from 5002. Kal-AOL is sent back in time via a [[Time travel|time machine]] made out of [[Video game console|video game systems]]. Despite having no superpowers, he tries to be a superhero. After some adventures as a Superhero, he and his friends decide to use their time machine to travel back to the origin of time and talk to God. Jack (who is never definitively stated to be God) takes Al and his friend through the times of the dinosaurs and neanderthals, explaining the origins of life and bestowing the secret of world peace to Al in the process. Al tries to have his story published as a series of comic books to share the secret of world peace, but is rejected because his story is not about superheroes or action. The title is a reference to the TV series ''[[Smallville]]''; the cover of issue #1 features the main character tied up as a [[scarecrow]] with a red 'M' painted on his chest, much as [[Tom Welling]] is in the [[Pilot (Smallville)|first episode]] of ''Smallville'' and in related publicity material. The series revisits several existing points of Marvel continuity in a completely irreverent and contradictory manner. For example, the issue titled "Originville" (referencing ''[[Origin (comics)|Origin]]'') visits a prehistoric setting in which [[Wolverine (character)|Wolverine]] is a mutant [[Neanderthal]]. Despite this, the series' main character, Kal-AOL Turner made a cameo appearance in the [[Marvel Universe]] series ''[[Great Lakes Avengers|GLA]]'' and received a profile in ''[[Official Handbook of the Marvel Universe|The All-New Official Handbook of the Marvel Universe A to Z]]''. Issue #3 consists entirely of art with the separations, with the script superimposed over it. The final issue of ''Marville'', issue #7, does not actually contain a story; instead, it contains the submissions guidelines to Marvel's new [[Epic Comics]] imprint.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fF0XachOwyYC&pg=PT643&dq=marville+comics&hl=en&sa=X&ei=r90cUZvmNOmKiAK5t4C4Ag&ved=0CD0Q6AEwAg |title=Marvel Comics: The Untold Story - Sean Howe - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-20}} ==U-Decide== Marville was created as part of Marvel's U-Decide promotional campaign, in which fans would decide which of three books would survive. The event involved one existing book ([[Peter David]]'s ''[[Captain Marvel (Marvel Comics)|Captain Marvel]]'', whose numbering was restarted at issue #1) and two new books (''Marville'' and Ron Zimmerman's ''[[Ultimate Adventures]]''), and was based around a bet between David and Jemas, of which Marvel editor-in-chief [[Joe Quesada]] later became a part. Jemas changed the stakes of the bet a few issues into ''Marville'', stating that the loser would take a pie in the face for charity. Despite this, both ''Marville'' and ''Ultimate Adventures'' ended fairly quickly, while the rebooted ''Captain Marvel'' would last 25 more issues, for a total of 60 issues when combined with the first run.{{fact|date=September 2018}} ==Reception== For its confusing plot, wanton sexuality, and thinly-veiled promotional nature, ''Marville'' was universally panned by critics, and is regularly referred to as one of the worst comics of all time.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thethings.com/the-15-worst-comics-ever-published/|title=The 15 Worst Comics Ever Published|date=2017-07-09|work=TheThings|access-date=2018-06-17|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/Machinima/status/866814450367582208|title=Machinima on Twitter|website=Twitter|language=en|access-date=2018-06-17}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.cgccomics.com/boards/topic/4178-marville-the-worst-comic-book-ever/|title=Marville: The Worst Comic Book EVER|website=CGC Comic Book Collectors Chat Boards|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-17}} ''[[Comics Alliance]]'' included ''Marville'' in their list of the 15 Worst Comics of the Decade, calling it little more than a "publicity stunt,Hudson, Laura (December 17, 2009). [http://comicsalliance.com/the-15-worst-comics-of-the-decade/ "The 15 Worst Comics of the Decade"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140924040315/http://comicsalliance.com/the-15-worst-comics-of-the-decade/ |date=2014-09-24 }}. Comics Alliance and Rob Bricken of [[io9]] likened the work to "shooting heroin directly into your adrenal gland."{{Cite news|url=https://io9.gizmodo.com/10-comics-marvel-would-desperately-like-to-forget-they-1508292020|title=10 Comics Marvel Would Desperately Like to Forget They Published|last=Bricken|first=Rob|work=io9|access-date=2018-06-17|language=en-US}} ''[[Screen Rant]]'' ranked Kal-AOL (and the rest of the Marville cast) as one of the superheroes that Marvel wants you to forget.{{cite web|last1=Byrd|first1=Matthew|title=15 Superheroes Marvel Wants You To Forget|url=http://screenrant.com/worst-superheroes-marvel-wants-you-to-forget-embarassing/|website=Screen Rant|accessdate=2 September 2017|date=29 August 2017}} ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' called it "abominable", "nearly unpublishable", and — despite its professional-quality production values — "fundamentally amateurish", condemning Jemas for using the Marvel corporation as "a [[vanity press]] for himself".[https://www.avclub.com/with-great-power-comes-a-bizarre-lack-of-responsibility-1798284127 With great power comes a bizarre lack of responsibility case file #44: ''Marville''], by Nathan Rabin, at ''[[The A.V. Club]]''; published September 10, 2015; retrieved July 15, 2018 ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Marvel Comics limited series]] [[Category:Parody comics]] [[Category:Satirical comics]] [[Category:2002 comics debuts]] [[Category:2003 comics endings]] [[Category:Parody superheroes]] [[Category:Neanderthals in fiction]]

{{distinguish|mode effect}} The '''modality effect''' is a term used in [[experimental psychology]], most often in the fields dealing with [[memory]] and [[learning]], to refer to how learner performance depends on the presentation mode of studied items.
==Description== Modality can refer to a number of characteristics of the presented study material. However, this term is usually used to describe the improved recall of the final items of a list when that list is presented verbally in comparison with a [[Visual perception|visual]] representation. The effect is seen in [[free recall]] (recall of list items in any given order), [[Recall (memory)#Serial recall|serial recall]] (recall of list items in the order of study), short-term sentence recall (recall specific words from sentences with similar meanings) and paired associate recall (recall of a pair from presentation of one of its members). For paired associates, the effect is limited to an increased probability of recall for the final 2 or 3 pairs studied.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Murdock|first=Bennet B.|title=Short-term Memory|journal=The psychology of learning and motivation:advances in research and theory|year=1972|volume=5|pages=67–127|doi=10.1016/s0079-7421(08)60440-5}}</ref> In free recall and serial recall, the modality effect is seen as simply an exaggerated recency effect in tests where presentation is auditory. In short-term sentence recall studies, emphasis is placed on words in a distractor-word list when requesting information from the remembered sentence. This demonstrates the modality effect can be more than auditory or visual.<ref name='Goolkasian'>{{cite journal | title = Modality Effects in Sentence Recall | journal = The Journal of General Psychology | year = 2009 | first = Paula | last = Goolkasian |author2=Paul W. Foos |author3=Mirrenda Eaton | volume = 136 | issue = 2 | pages = 205–224| id = | url = http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.3200/GENP.136.2.205-224 | accessdate = 2012-01-26 | pmid=19350835 | doi=10.3200/GENP.136.2.205-224}}</ref>
For serial recall, the modality effect is seen in an increased [[memory span]] for auditorally presented lists. Memory span is defined as the maximum number of items that participants correctly recall in 50% of trials. Typically, studies find these to be seven digits, six letters and five words.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Crannell|first=C.W.|author2=Parish, J.M.|title=A comparison of immediate memory span for digits, letters and words|journal=Journal of Psychology|year=1957|volume=44|pages=319–327|doi=10.1080/00223980.1957.9713089}}</ref> In a study done by Drewnowski and Murdock, a visual list of English words was found to have an immediate recall of 4.82 words while an auditory representation of this same list led to a memory span of 5.36, a statistically significant variance.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Drewnowski|first=Adam|author2=Murdock, B.B.|title=The role of auditory features in memory span for words|journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology: Human Learning and Memory|year=1980|volume=6|pages=319–332|doi=10.1037/0278-7393.6.3.319}}</ref>
Some studies use the term modality to refer to a general difference in performance based upon the mode of presentation. For example, Gibbons demonstrated modality effects in an experiment by making participants count either beeping sounds or visually presented dots. The to-be-remembered number was derived from the number of dots or beeps counted.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gibbons|first=Jeffrey A.|author2=Velkey, Andrew K. |author3=Partin, Kathren T. |title=Influence of recall procedures on the modality effect with numbers and enumerated stimuli|journal=Journal of General Psychology|date=January 2008|volume=135|pages=84–104|doi=10.3200/genp.135.1.84-104}}</ref> In memory experiments, the modality effect is an example of source clustering, which refers to the tendency of items presented in the same modality to be grouped together during recall.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Kahana|first=Michael J.|author2=Polyn, Sean M. |author3=Norman, Keith A. |title=A Context Maintenance and Retrieval Model of Organizational Processes in Free Recall|journal=Psychological Review|year=2009|volume=116|pages=129–156|doi=10.1037/a0014420}}</ref> Within-list manipulations of modality affect recall probability, order of recall, and grouping.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Murdock|first=Benet B.|author2=Walker, Keith D.|title=Modality Effects in Free Recall|journal=Journal of Verbal Learning and Verbal Behavior|year=1969|volume=8|pages=665–676|doi=10.1016/s0022-5371(69)80120-9}}</ref>
[[Bennet Murdock]] used a basic free recall paradigm, with different types of lists, mixing auditorally and visually presented words. The results he obtained showed that modality improved [[recency]] but did not affect recall for the pre-recency items. This effect was seen to be slightly larger when the items for study were presented more rapidly.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Murdock|first=Bennet B.|author2=Walker, Kenneth D.|title=Modality effects in free recall|journal=Journal of Verbal Leaning and Verbal Behavior|year=1969|volume=8|pages=665–676|doi=10.1016/s0022-5371(69)80120-9}}</ref> However, with mixed list presentations (lists presented both auditorally and visually in a single study period) the superiority of auditory study is seen in all serial positions, not just in recency. Murdock interprets this as evidence for separate short term stores for visual and auditory memory.
Glenberg<ref>{{cite journal|last=Glenberg|first=Arthur M.|title=A retrieval account of the long-term modality effect|journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition|date=January 1984|volume=10|pages=16–31|doi=10.1037/0278-7393.10.1.16}}</ref> showed that the modality effect is also prevalent in [[Long-term memory|long term memory]], showing that to-be-remembered word pairs that are separated by distractor activity are better recalled if presented auditorally vs. visually. By using techniques similar to Murdock’s free recall paradigm, plus the addition of varied amounts of distraction time (filled with counting backwards), Glenberg showed that the modality effect is not affected by a disruptive task and therefore is theoretically not restricted to [[Short-term memory|short term memory]].
Several terms have been used to refer to the modality effect on recency. Crowder and Morton<ref>{{cite journal|last=Crowder|first=Robert G.|author2=Morton, John|title=Precategorical acoustic storage (PAS)|journal=Perception & Psychophysics|year=1969|volume=5|pages=365–373|doi=10.3758/bf03210660}}</ref> refer to it as PAS, or precategorical acoustic store. This and other similar terms([[echoic memory]], [[Baddeley's model of working memory#Phonological loop|phonological loop]]) are used to explain a specialized short-term memory system store for phonological information.<ref>{{cite book|last=Baddeley|first=A.D.|title=Working Memory|year=1986|publisher=Clarendon Press|location=Oxford, England}}</ref>

[[File:Mozarteumorchester Salzburg.jpg|thumb|The Mozarteum Orchestra Salzburg]] [[File:Ein Konzert des Mozarteumorchesters Salzburg.jpg|thumb|A concert at the [[Großes Festspielhaus|Great Festival Hall]], Salzburg]] The '''Mozarteum Orchestra Salzburg''' is an Austrian orchestra, based in the town and [[States of Austria|state]] of [[Salzburg]]. The orchestra gives concerts in several Salzburg venues, including the ''[[Großes Festspielhaus]]'', the Great Hall of the [[International Mozarteum Foundation|Stiftung Mozarteum]]. In addition to symphony orchestra concerts, the orchestra serves as accompanying ensemble for operas and musical theatre performances at the [[Salzburger Landestheater|Salzburg State Theater]].
The ensemble was founded in 1841 with the help of [[Mozart]]’s sons [[Franz Xaver Mozart|Franz Xaver]] and [[Karl Thomas Mozart|Karl Thomas]], as well as his widow [[Constanze Mozart|Constanze]], under the musical direction of Alois Taux. In 1908, the ensemble officially adopted the name "Mozarteum Orchestra". The Mozarteum Orchestra participates regularly at the [[Salzburg Festival]], such as in the Festival's 'Mozart Matinees'. It also performs several concerts at the Salzburg Mozart Week and for the Salzburg Cultural Association.
In 2008, the Mozarteum Orchestra began a young project, '2 ORCHESTRAS', which presents new works for the combination of a professional orchestra and a youth orchestra.<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://service.salzburg.gv.at/lkorrj/Index?cmd=detail_ind&nachrid=41714 | title=Musik vereint Jugend aus aller Welt | publisher=Land Salzburg | date=29 October 2008 | accessdate=2016-12-28}}</ref> Composers who have written works for this project have included [[Kurt Schwertsik]]<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.salzburg24.at/2-orchestras-mozarteum-orchester-salzburg-vergibt-5-auftragswerke/news-20080806-02591898 | title="2 Orchestras": Mozarteum Orchester Salzburg vergibt 5 Auftragswerke | work=Salzburg 24 | author= | date=2008-08-06 | accessdate=2016-12-28}}</ref> and [[Toshio Hosokawa]].
The orchestra's most recent chief conductor was [[Ivor Bolton]], from 2004 to 2016. Bolton now has the title of ''Ehrendirigent'' (Honorary Conductor) with the orchestra. In September 2016, Riccardo Minasi made his first guest-conducting appearance with the orchestra. In December 2016, the orchestra announced the appointment of Minasi as its next chief conductor, effective September 2017.<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.mozarteumorchester.at/pressemeldungen-reader/weisser-rauch-beim-mozarteumorchester-salzburg-riccardo-minasi-wird-neuer-chefdirigent.html | title=Weißer Rauch beim Mozarteumorchester Salzburg: Riccardo Minasi wird neuer Chefdirigent | publisher=Mozarteum Orchestra Salzburg | date=19 December 2016 | accessdate=2016-12-28}}</ref> Past principal guest conductors of the orchestra have included [[Trevor Pinnock]]. The orchestra's current principal guest conductor is [[Giovanni Antonini]].
The Mozarteum Orchestra has recorded commercially for such labels as Oehms Classics, Sony Classical, and Naive.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/sep/11/spohr-die-letzten-dinge-cd-review | title=Spohr: Die Letzten Dinge CD review – fine singing from the Salzburg Bach Choir | work=The Guardian | author=Tim Ashley | date=2014-09-11 | accessdate=2016-12-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/sep/18/mozart-arias-cd-review-sandrine-piau | title=Mozart: Arias CD review – Sandrine Piau is wonderfully stylish | work=The Guardian | author=Andrew Clements | date=2014-10-18 | accessdate=2016-12-28}}</ref>
